Title: Non farm employment in the context of growing rural-urban linkages. (The case of corridor villages in Yogyakarta Special Region - Indonesia)
Authors with affiliations: Rijanta, R.
Abstract: An intensive single visit survey and rapid rural appraisal are conducted, covering three villages (Maguwoharjo, Kembang, Putat) in Yogyakarta Special Region. To some extent a qualitative information is also available for two additional villages of Pendowoharjo and Murtigading. This enables to draw a more complete picture of rural-urban linkage from and to all directions between Yogyakarta Municipality and its vicinity. The study reveals that the surveyed villages have experienced a great spatial and socio-economic transformation. Continuous provision of infrastructural support from the government has led to a better integration of rural areas to the main regional center of Yogyakarta Municipality. The most evident spatial changes are found in terms of land use in the main corridors from Yogyakarta Municipality to various directions. Employment structure is characterized by the importance of non-farm activities related to the urban sector. Service and trading activities are the most important source of employment for those who conduct commuting, either as employees or independent workers in both urban formal and informal sectors. Another type of non-farm employment is food processing and services are to be found in situ in the growing rural urban zone. This type of employment is simply a form of adjustment to local circumstances in which higher population density provides more accessible threshold for various goods and services offered. Sectoral and spatial linkages of the existing non-farm employment is rather limited in terms of economic multiplier effects. Further employment and income generation linkages are almost negligible. Finally, two sets of policy options consisting of agricultural development and infrastructural provision are proposed in order to anticipate the growing importance of rural urban linkage in the future for the benefit of the rural areas.
Index Keywords: agricultural development; infrastructural provision; labour absorption; land use change; off-farm employment; rural-urban linkage; Indonesia, Java, Yogyakarta

Title: Popular perception and participation in land and water conservation: a case of Wonogiri District
Authors with affiliations: Sutanto, A.
Abstract: In comparison with lowland area, the upland area has been less prioritized in the development scheme and relatively left behind in the introduction of productive technology. Additionally, physical condition of the dry-upland becomes major problem for people to gain a better welfare. There is now steadily an increasing government concern and awareness of the importance of this area. Despite the development equity jargon, the recognition of the significance of upland lies to the face that upland position is not only substantial but also decisive within watershed system. Land and water conservation work on these spheres of upland attractiveness. The study is directed to the inventory of this land and water conservation activities as a mean of development interventions to upland. Furthermore, appraising popular perception and participation in the activities is also the main part of the objective of the study. To facilitate this objective achievement, the study is purposely conducted in one of upland regency in Central Java, namely Wonogir. Two villages within the regency have been selected on the basis of agro-ecological stratification and within each village an amount of 150 farmer respondents has been randomly selected and interviewed.
Index Keywords: developing country; development planning; land conservation; popular participation; popular perception; upland management; water conservation; Indonesia, Java, Wonogiri

Title: Geomorphology of Yogyakarta area and its surrounding proposed as a geomorphological field laboratory
Authors with affiliations: Sutikno
Abstract: Almost all of the genetic geomorphological units exist in this area, except glacial. The geomorphological land classification closely relate to the physical environment components such as topography, soil, hydrology and land use/land cover. The geomorphological land classifications also reflect natural hazards such as flood, drought, erosion, massmovement and volcanic (nue ardente and lahars flow). Based on the completeness of geomorphological phenomena, Yogyakarta area and its surroundings show promise as a training area (field laboratory) for students from geography, physical, geography, geomorphology and other earth sciences.
Index Keywords: geomorphological research; land classification; Indonesia, Java, Yogyakarta Region

Title: Rainfall interception loss of logged-over area of central Kalimantan (Part II)
Affiliations: Fac of Agric, Padjadjaran Univ, Jatinangor, Cikeruh 45363, Sumedang West Java, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Asdak, C., Fac of Agric, Padjadjaran Univ, Jatinangor, Cikeruh 45363, Sumedang West Java, Indonesia
Abstract: Rainfall interception losses were monitored for eight months and related to vegetation and rainfall characteristics at the BPK-ODA research site in the upper stream of Mentaya river, Central Kalimantan. Over eight months in one hectare of logged-over forest area 172.2 mm (6.4%) of 2682 mm gross rainfall occuring in the research area was 'loss' to the atmosphere. Canopy throughfall equaled 2503 mm (93%) of gross rainfall whereas stemflow represented 6.8 mm (0.25%).
Index Keywords: forest; logging; rainfall interception; stemflow; throughfall; Indonesia, Kalimantan, Mentaya River
Correspondence Address: Asdak, C.; Fac of Agric, Padjadjaran Univ, Jatinangor, Cikeruh 45363, Sumedang West Java, Indonesia

Title: Groundwater conservation on Bekasi District west Java, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Dasanto, B.D.
Abstract: The District has developed rapidly for industry and settlement, and this has had a negative impact on environmental carrying capacity. This study aims to estimate the groundwater potential capacity and supply up to the year 2000, and to produce conservation techniques to sustain local needs. Using the supply-demand method, shows that the supply should be adequate in most regions up to 2000. The water conservation techniques which can be applied include the enforcement of regulations and limiting groundwater exploitation.
Index Keywords: conservation technique; developing country; groundwater conservation; water demand; water management; water resources management; Indonesia, Java, West, Bekasi District

Title: The eruption of Merapi volcano, November 22, 1994: a geographical review
Authors with affiliations: Sudibyakto; Abasi, S.H.
Abstract: This paper discusses the extent of the eruption of the Merapi volcano on 22 November 1994. It looks at the effects associated with the volcano as it erupted in 1994. The damages were inflicted on both the abiotic and biotic environments. The eruption occurred in the southern parts of the volcano and the nuee ardente was witnessed between Turgo and Kaliurang hills via the Boyong river. Various volcanic materials were emitted on to the surface, including lava flows, gases, volcanic ash, sand and big blocks. The heavy rainfall which accompanied the eruption led to the formation of rain lahars, which also posed a threat in the lower portions of the volcano. Hugh volumes of volcanic materials found their way into the Boyong river and neighbouring rivers in the west, resulting in lahar floods. Some prognoses have been put forward as predictions or the outcomes of Merapi eruption both in the short-term and the long-term. These are only estimations intended to judge the consequences which may be desirable or undesirable. This situation has called for government involvement in an attempt to mimize casualties. This has been enabled through intergovernmental co-operation through the establishment of disaster prevention projects like the Sabo Technical Centre, Merapi Volcano Project and the office concerned with the investigation of the activites of Merapi. These projects have been combined in an attempt to establish hazard maps of the area.
Index Keywords: disaster prevention; hazard impact; hazard map; hazard mapping; natural hazard; planning implication; volcanic eruption; volcanic hazard; Indonesia, Java, Merapi Volcano

Title: Agricultural production and land-use pattern in Kgatleng District, Botswana
Authors with affiliations: Lado, C.
Abstract: Land-use is in a continuous process of change either planned or otherwise. An increase in population has resulted into additional need for more agricultural land. The cattle population has increased relatively in line with population growth. This paper examines the changes in land-use pattern related to crop production and cattle rearing. Traditionally, crop production and cattle raising were conducted as separate enterprises. However, cattle have been recently kept on agricultural land, thus leading to extensive crop damage. In Kgatleng district, this development occurred in the 1920s with the establishment of the borehole scheme. Grazing areas are considered to be overrulitized, hence necessitating land-use intensification, including the adoption of 'modern' agricultural techniques and practices so as to minimize land deterioration and achieve sustainable production.
Index Keywords: developing country; land degradation; land use pattern; livestock farming; man-environment relations; population pressure; Botswana, Kgatleng District

Authors: Dimyati M., Mizuno K., Kobayashi S., Kitamura T.
Title: A method for estimation of macroscopic land suitability using remote sensing and geographic information systems: a case study in Yogyakarta, Indonesia
Affiliations: PUSDATA, Min of Public Works, J1 Pattimura 20, Jakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Dimyati, M., PUSDATA, Min of Public Works, J1 Pattimura 20, Jakarta, Indonesia; Mizuno, K., PUSDATA, Min of Public Works, J1 Pattimura 20, Jakarta, Indonesia; Kobayashi, S., PUSDATA, Min of Public Works, J1 Pattimura 20, Jakarta, Indonesia; Kitamura, T., PUSDATA, Min of Public Works, J1 Pattimura 20, Jakarta, Indonesia
Abstract: Satellite images and thematic information were used for the estimation of macroscopic current land suitability for paddy and settlement. These data were analyzed by a quantitative method known as quantification-2 theory with the aid of remote sensing and geographic information systems. Six variables, consisting of two thematic information and four satellite images, were selected for the estimation of land suitability for paddy into three cases and for settlement into two cases. The results show that the combination of satellite images alone performed a reliable role for the estimation of macroscopic current land suitability. The land suitability score could be objectively quantified by introducing this method.
Index Keywords: developing country; GIS; land suitability; land use classification; land use planning; paddy field; remote sensing; settlement; Indonesia, Java, Yogyakarta
Correspondence Address: Dimyati, M.; PUSDATA, Min of Public Works, J1 Pattimura 20, Jakarta, Indonesia

Title: The perceptions and aspirations of people residing in the dangerous zone of Merapi volcano on their settlement environment
Authors with affiliations: Yunus, H.S.
Abstract: This article attempts find out the behavioural characteristics of people residing in the dangerous zone of Merapi volcano relating to their aspirations and perceptions of their settlement environment. The research is based on in-depth interviews. The research has been realised through co-operation between the Faculty of Geography Gadjah Mada University and the Department of Transmigration, Yogyakarta Special Province. Some 350 respondents were interviewed within 6 sample areas. Three sample areas are located on the volcanic slopes of the volcano, classified as the most dangerous zone, whereas the other three are located along the banks of river flowing down from the Merapi volcano. The first group is dangerous because of nuee ardente whereas the second group is dangerous because of the so-called rain lahar flows. The result of the research shows that most respondents (65%) do not feel agraid of the danger of either the nuee ardente or the rain lahar, 18% feel afraid and the rest (17%) very afraid of the danger. 94% of people wish to remain living in the village and only 6% of them would like to move.
Index Keywords: developing country; hazard perception; natural hazard; perception; Indonesia, Java, Merapi Volcano

Title: Variation of nocturnal surface temperature within suburban residential land use: a case study on suburban Fairfield, western Sydney, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Kirono, D.G.C.
Abstract: This article deals with nocturnal variation of surface temperature within suburban Fairfield, Western Sydney, based on field observations. The data was acquired by traversing a route consisted of 45 measurement points. The measurements were conducted at 6, 7, 8 and 9pm respectively. The results show that there were both spatial and temporal variations of surface temperature over the study area, particularly when the individual surface type was considered. It was observed that the variations are caused by some factors, i.e. anthropogenic heat, radiation trapping, wind shelter and katabatic flow. The results also show that there was a quite good relation between the air and surface temperature. This can be a base in developing a method for observing heat islands using thermal remote sensing technique in the future.
Index Keywords: air temperature; land use; nocturnal temperature; regional weather pattern; surface temperature; urban area; Australia, New South Wales, Sydney

Title: Land degradation of urban area on fluvio volcanic plain (case study of Yogyakarta urba area)
Affiliations: Dept of Phys Geog, Gadjah Mada Univ, Fac of Geog, Yogyakarta, Indonesia, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Sutikno, Dept of Phys Geog, Gadjah Mada Univ, Fac of Geog, Yogyakarta, Indonesia, Indonesia
Abstract: The results of the study shows that the land degradation of Yogyakarta urban areas are caused by erosion of land surface in the settlement area, erosion on the road segments, deposition on the road segments and drainage channels, inundation on the roads and mass movement to the river banks. Variation of the erosion rate in the settlement area related to the settlement density. Sediment yield from the settlement and road were deposited on the drainage channels. This condition effects the decreasing of channel capacity. During the heavy rain, water overflow inundates some of the road segments for about 30-40 cm thick within 30 minutes. Lateral erosion, and undercutting along the river courses and accelerated by anthropogenic process effects to the rising the mass movement processes along the river banks. There are two factors of geomorphic processes causing the land degradation in the urban areas of Yogyakarata, namely surface run off after heavy rain and human activities. -from Author
Index Keywords: anthropogenic impact; fluviovolcanic plain; land degradation; runoff; urban area; Indonesia; Yogyakarta

Title: Evaluation of the Dong model for estimation of net radiation at Sydney and Alice Spring, Australia
Authors with affiliations: Kirono, D.G.C.
Abstract: A model developed by Dong et al. (1992) to estimate hourly and daytime net radiation (Q*) using the available meteorological data is evaluated. Originally, the model was generated and designated for well-watered grass in the California region. Evaluation of the model by the writer was conducted at two sites, ie Sydney and Alice Springs, Australia. The former represents a grass surface type while the latter is a desert surface type. The results show that the formula is excellent. It was found that for grass site the correlation between the calculated and measured hourly net radiation is 0.99, while for the desert site it is about 0.97. -from Authors
Index Keywords: adjustment policy; Dong model; IMF; investment; model evaluation; net radiation; structural adjustment; surface vegetation; World Bank; Africa; Alice Springs; Australia; New South Wales; Northern Territory; Sydney

Title: Rural-urban fertility differentials in Bendel State: myth or reality
Affiliations: Dept Geog & Regional Planning, Delta State Univ Abraka, Abaraka, Delta State, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Ugbomeh, B.A., Dept Geog & Regional Planning, Delta State Univ Abraka, Abaraka, Delta State, Nigeria
Abstract: The paper examines fertility differentials between the rural and urban areas of the former Bendel State. Studies in the 1960s show no discernible pattern of rural-urban fertility differentials in Africa Nigeria inclusive. Although some studies have recorded urban fertility being actually higher than the rural, others have shown the contrary with the rural areas having higher fertility level. There is, therefore, the need for a clarification of the controversy. The present paper aims at filling this gap by establishing if fertility differentials between both communities are myth or reality in Bendel State. -Author
Index Keywords: comparative studies; developing country; fertility difference; fertility rate; population fertility; rural- urban comparison; rural-urban differentials; Bendel State; Nigeria

Title: Rural diversification under varying geographical conditions: an exploratory survey of four clusters of small-scale industry in Bantul district, Special Region of Yogyakarta
Authors with affiliations: Huisman, H.; Kragten, M.
Abstract: The last decades, rural East and Southeast Asia have been experiencing remarkable economic transformations. In the process of rural diversification in Java considerable regional differences can be observed. These spatial aspects of rural diversification form the central theme in this article. After a brief discussion of theoretical issues, the characteristics of the small-scale industrial enterprises and households in four clusters of small-scale industry situated in varying rural contexts are presented. An attempt is made to assess the extent in which local factors, among which agricultural structure and relative location, can be held responsible for the differences observed. -from Authors
Index Keywords: developing region; regional differences; regional disparity; rural diversification; small and medium-sized enterprise; small-scale industry; spatial analysis; Bantul; Bantul District; Indonesia; Java; Yogyakara; Yogyakarta

Title: Assessment of groundwater resources at the Beach Ridges of the Kulon Progo district, Yogyakarta, Indonesia
Affiliations: Physical Geography Dept., Gadjah Mada Univ, Yogyakarta, Indonesia, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Sudarmadji, Physical Geography Dept., Gadjah Mada Univ, Yogyakarta, Indonesia, Indonesia
Abstract: The Southern part of The Yogyakarta special Province and The Central Java Province mostly consist of coastal alluvial plain and beach ridges. The possible groundwater utilization in the future are for the agricultural, domestic and tourism needs. The study was conducted to a), identify groundwater condition of the area, b) identify possible salt water intrusion into the aquifer. The groundwater flow out of the area is about 276 mm, while only about 7 mm is used for domestic use, the groundwater storage is 987 mm per year. Salt water intrusion was detected. The salinity of shallow groundwater is relatively low, which cause no objection of groundwater use for domestic and irrigation purposes. -from Author
Index Keywords: coastal alluvial plain; groundwater resource; groundwater salinity; salt water intrusion; Indonesia; Kulon Progo District; Yogyakarta

Title: The economic space of Nigeria's federal capital territory
Authors with affiliations: Balogun, O.
Abstract: The dualistic theory is utilized as the framework for this analysis of the emerging spatial pattern of development in Nigeria's Federal Capital Territory (FCT). The analysis is carried out using the principal axis method of factoring the data set. The scores of the extracted orthogonal factors are mapped and interpreted in spatial terms. The space economy of our study area is observed to conform with the dualistic theory in two major ways. That is, both economic systems cluster in space with a discernible pattern, and there is in existence a regional dualism. It is suggested that the development of an asymetrical relationship between the two structural components of the observed spatial dualism must be prevented by adopting appropriate regional development policies. -from Author
Index Keywords: developing country; development pattern; dualism; economic analysis; economic development; regional dualism; regional inequality; spatial analysis; urban economy; Federal Capital Territory; Nigeria

Title: The dilemma of food in Africa
Authors with affiliations: Kaloko, F.R.
Abstract: Although over 70% of the labour force is engaged in agriculture, Africa is losing the capacity to feed iteself. Drought, a fast growing population, widespread deterioration of the countryside, as well as a chronic underinvestment in agriculture, have all contributed to declining yields and a vicious cycle of poverty from which the peasant farmer and African countries have increasingly found it difficult to escape. The need therefore is most urgent for African governments to re-examine their food and agricultural policies to enable them to provide more food for their growing population. Encouragment of large and medium scale commercial farming, land reform, environmental management, reduction of population growth, improvement in storage and transport facilities as well as pursue political stability and a cessation of the violent conflicts that have characterized the continent, will reduce the food problem in Africa. -Author
Index Keywords: agricultural policy; developing region; drought; environmental degradation; famine; food security; food supply; infrastructure planning; Africa

Title: Contingent valuation of watershed protection in Nigeria: a case study
Authors with affiliations: Olokesusi, F.
Abstract: This paper focusses on the use of the willingness-to-pay (WTP) approach for determining the amount of money that people in selected large-scale irrigation and dam project areas in the Sudano-Sahelian zone of Nigeria are willing to forego for the sake of environmental protection in the watershed. After a general description of the problems and approaches to valuing and monetising environmental resources and their protection, the details of the study findings and policy implications are discussed. The three major irrigation and dam projects, used as case study are: the Kano River Project (KPR) in Kano State; the Bakolori Irrigation Project (BIP) in Sokoto state; and the South Chad Irrigation Project (SCIP) Phase I in Borno State. -from Author
Index Keywords: contingent valuation; dam project; developing country; environmental economics; environmental protection; irrigation; watershed management; watershed protection; willingness to pay; Nigeria; Sahel

Title: Spatial determinants of import traffic distribution at Port Harcourt (Nigeria)
Authors with affiliations: Inyang, S.I.
Abstract: This paper highlights the result of a study carried out to examine the geographic determinants of import traffic distribution at the Port Harcourt Port. A substantial aspect of the study involved building a regression model to estimate import distribution from the Port. The import function was specified in log-linear form. The adequacy of the model was then tested; this, involved statistical experiments to obtain the R-squared, as well as t and f values. Further test on the adequacy of the model was conducted through diagnostic exercises designed to check for multicollinearity and heteroscedasticity, in the data used. Results obtained show that road distance and manufacturing industries are significant Geographic determinants of import Cargo distribution at the study Port. It is therefore important to take the two variables into account in any policy or planning exercise at Port Harcourt Port. -Author
Index Keywords: developing country; import distribution; import traffic; modelling approach; port development; regression model; spatial analysis; traffic distribution; transport planning; transport system; Nigeria; Port Harcourt; Rivers State

Title: Rural diversification, non-farm employment and the central town: a case study of Jatinom, central Java
Authors with affiliations: Effendi, T.N.
Abstract: This study examines the effects of diversification of the rural economy on the role of central town in rural development. Data are based on a listing of non-farm enterprises in Jatinom subdistrict and on a household survey undertaken in three villages in the same subdistrict. By analysing the location of non-farm work place, marketing system, location where the household went for service needs, and the provision of non-farm employment this study found that small town has strengthened its function as market and service center for the rural hinterland. However, its role in the provision of non-farm employment and enhancing rural development is limited. -Author
Index Keywords: diversification effect; employment generation; non-farm employment; off-farm employment; rural development; rural diversification; rural economy; service centre; spatial analysis; Central; Indonesia; Jatinom; Java

Title: Application of remote sensing for identification of hydrological characteristics and erosion-sedimentation process in catchment area of Gadjahmungkur reservoir Wonogiri, central Java, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Gunawan, T.
Abstract: The catchment area of Gadjahmungkur reservoir is situated in Wonogiri District, Central Java, Indonesia. One of the problems to be found in the area is the existing of relatively high erosion-sedimentation process running into reservoir. Several causes that provoke the erosion-sedimentation processes are hydrological characteristics, relatively low awareness of population to sustainable natural resources development and agricultural human activities on the catchment area. Socio-bio-physical analysis is one of the problem solving alternatives that can be applied for the area. In this case, remote sensing technique is a useful tool for evaluation and monitoring hydrological characteristics and erosion-sedimentation process of the area. -Author
Index Keywords: erosion; hydrology; remote sensing; reservoir; sedimentation; Gadjahmungkur; Indonesia; Java; Tengah; Wonogiri

Title: House use orientation (HUO) in the urban fringe areas: a case study of Ngestiharjo, Bantul, Yogyakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Yunus, H.S.
Abstract: This article deals with an interesting, phenomenon in the urban fringe area of the City of Yogyakarta, Indonesia, ie the changing house use orientation (HUO). The influx of urban structures and functions together with new immigrants into the fringe areas has stimulated the increase of activities and the number of residents. The need for accommodation has increased tremendously and this phenomenon has triggered the awareness of the fringe residents to the economic functions of their house they can obtain and from then the residents commence to change their sole function of house (non commercial HUO) into more commercial oriented in character. One of the subdistricts in the fringe areas of the city of Yogyakarta is chosen as an example, ie Ngestiharjo subdistrict. An even distribution of respondents over the study area is pursued through the called "systematic proportional random sampling technique'. Four main categories of commercial HUO can be identified in the fringe areas viz. Shops, boarding house with shops, boarding house and others. No commercial HUO constitutes activities of family's daily routines without any additional incomes the residents earn from these activities. The higher the accessibility of a given location, the higher the frequency of houses with double orientation. -from Author
Index Keywords: commercial use; developing country; economic strategy; house use orientation; housing location; urban fringe; Indonesia; Java; Ngestiharjo; Yogyakarta

Title: The volcanoes of Indonesia and natural disaster reduction (with some examples)
Affiliations: Intl Inst for Aerospace, P.O.B. 6, Enscede, NSW, The Netherlands, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Verstappen, H.T., Intl Inst for Aerospace, P.O.B. 6, Enscede, NSW, The Netherlands, Netherlands
Abstract: Indonesian volcanism is related to the subduction (Benioff) zones of the Indo-Australian and the Pacific-Philippine plates at the contact with the Asian plate. Strato volcanoes and also ignimbrite plateaus associated with socalled "volcano-tectonic' depressions of deep-seated faults are major features. Fluvio-volcanic flows and slopes are common due to the humid tropical climate. Large volcanic landslides and debris flows causing rupture of crater or caldera rims and the collapse of slopes also are important volcanic geomorphological features. The role of geomorphological survey and the use of aerospace technology in volcanic hazard zoning is emphasized. -Author
Index Keywords: debris flow; developing country; geomorphological survey; geomorphology; hazard mapping; hazard zoning; landslide; natural hazard; remote sensing; slope collapse; subduction zone; volcanic activity; volcanic hazard; Indonesia

Title: The role of small groups in innovation diffusion and its implications for rural development
Authors with affiliations: Ariyo, J.A.
Abstract: This study is an attempt to investigate what people do when an innovation comes along which leads to its adoption or rejection. The purpose is to gain an insight into the behavioural aspect of the diffusion research in geography. Participants in a survey of the diffusion of commercial tobacco growing in some rural communities in the Zaria region Nigeria, alluded constantly to the influence of their membership of variety of clubs and volunatary association in their decision to adopt the innovation. The following group variables were revealed as the major factors which influenced their decision to adopt commercial tobacco growing: group goals, norms, cohesion, structure, status, roles, style of leadership, communication and decision-making. The interactant effects of these small group variables as observed in the study area imply that for effectiveness in promoting innovation adoption to aid rapid rural development, there is need for identification and thorough understanding of rural target communities, experimentation with rural pilot groups, reducing the forces opposed to an innovation, and democratising innovation diffusion programmes. -from Author
Index Keywords: behavioural aspect; decision making; developing country; group membership; innovation adoption; innovation diffusion; policy implication; rural development; small- group role; tobacco production; Nigeria; Zaria

Title: The influence of population mobility on human settlements
Authors with affiliations: Lado, C.
Abstract: This paper examines some of the characteristics of world's population mobility, cultural environment and changing societies. Some of the national and international problems associated with population data collection and enumeration are explored including transient and temporary population movements. In analyzing population mobility and demographic transition, Zelinky's hypothesis is used as a conceptual framework applicable in both developed and developing conntries. The findings of the study focuses mainly on some of government policies and implications essential for rural-orientated and urban-orientated development programmes. It is emphasized that to achieve some of the socio-economic development objectives in any nation, it is important to have a comprehensive understanding of all the processes of mobility to match the various government policies of the redistribution. -Author
Index Keywords: data collection; demographic transition; population mobility; settlement characteristics; societal change; Zelinky's hypothesis

Title: A seismic analysis of valleyfill deposits
Authors with affiliations: Salleh, K.O.
Abstract: The FS-3 Portable Facsimile Seismograph - a single channel time-distance plotting instrument was used in the analysis of valleyfill deposits for semi-arid drainage basins. A multiple regression analysis was performed to determine the main controls of the volume of the valleyfills, thus giving an insight into the erosion and depositional system of semi-arid areas in general and of the study area in particular. -from Author
Index Keywords: erosion; Erosion; Seismic Methods; seismic survey; Seismicity; Semi Arid; semi arid environment; valley fill; Valleyfill

Title: Comparison of Landsat (MSS) and SPOT (XS) data for mapping and monitoring mangrove in Java, Indonesia
Affiliations: Faculty of Civil Engineering and Planning, Institute Technology of Sepuluh November Surabaya, Surabaya, Indonesia, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Muljosukojo, B., Faculty of Civil Engineering and Planning, Institute Technology of Sepuluh November Surabaya, Surabaya, Indonesia, Indonesia
Abstract: The accuracy of Landsat 5 Multispectral Scanner (MSS) data for mapping mangrove in Java is investigated and compared with SPOT 1 very High-Resolution Scanner (XS) data. Results produce overall mangrove area classification accuracies of 74.2 and 82.8% for MSS and XS with 7 and 10 classes, respectively. While the accuracies for predominant categories are similar for both sensors, mangrove discrimination for less commonly occuring and/or spatially heterogeneous categories is improved with the XS data set. The MSS, however, performs similar, or better than the XS in classifying large homogeneous areas. The use of MSS data which is expensive than high resolution data appears promising for mangrove monitoring. -from Author
Index Keywords: Landsat v. Spot; mangrove; mangrove swamps; multispectral scanner; satellite sensing; SPOT; Indonesia; Java

Title: Wet lands and their prospects in Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Sutikno; Sunarto, K.
Abstract: Indonesia has a very large amount of wet lands, most of them are unutilised yet. In national development planning wet lands data concerning the type, area and distribution are not available. Aims of this study are to inventory wet lands and their characteristics in Indonesia, and to estimate prospects of wet lands utilisation. A wet land mapping method is used to inventory the type, and the areal distribution; spatial and ecological approaches used to estimate the prospects of the utilization. The results of this study are the type and areal distribution of wet lands in each province of Indonesia. Wet lands have a good prospect for national development. Based on national regulation of land use planning, some utilization types should be reevaluated because of the deviation to the regulation. -Authors
Index Keywords: developing country; inventory preparation; mapping technique; regional pattern; wetland mapping; Indonesia

Title: Feminization of agriculture without loss of productivity and income: a case study from Nyeri district - Kenya
Affiliations: Dept of Geography, MOI Univ PO Box 3900 Eldoret, Kenya, Kenya
Authors with affiliations: Nyakaana, J.B., Dept of Geography, MOI Univ PO Box 3900 Eldoret, Kenya, Kenya
Abstract: Farming is the most important economic activity for developing countries. It has been regarded as a male dominated activity which is bound to suffer in terms of total production and productivity if left in the hands of women. This stems from the notion that women are not capable of successfully carrying out the "heavy' agricultural tasks which are performed by men leave alone being good farm managers. In an attempt to prove the validity of this notion, the author of this paper set out between March and July, 1990 to conduct a research on agricultural production in Mbogoini village in Nyeri District, Kenya. The aim and purpose of the research was to try and establish if there was any significant difference in agricultural production between men managed farms and female managed farms. This research was conducted by employing oral interviews with husbands and wives (separately) on 59 randomly chosen households on the basis of interview schedules. The results of the research have shown that women are not only capable of successfully carrying out the bulk of the heavy agricultural tasks but also are better farm managers than men. This has greatly contributed not only to increased total agricultural production but also productivity in areas where women are actively involved in agriculture as decision makers as evidenced in Mbogoini village of Nyeri district. -from Author
Index Keywords: agricultural production; comparative studies; developing country; farm management; production difference; women farmers; women's role; Kenya; Mbogoini; Nyeri District

Title: Regional development planning in Malaysia - an overview
Authors with affiliations: Ghaffar, F.A.
Abstract: In Malaysia, regional development planning has been carried out with the major aim of overcoming and in the long run eliminating the problem of regional inequalities. This paper traces the evaluation of regional development planning in this country, highlighting the major policies formulated, as well as strategies and programs inplemented. The major issues and problems are identified and the need for reform in this field suggested. This paper aims to provide an overview of regional development planning in this country and outlines the future direction of this field. -from Author
Index Keywords: developing country; economic development; planning evaluation; regional development; regional planning; Malaysia

Title: The role of rural small-scale industries in local linkage: a case study of four villages in Ciomas District, Bogor County, West-Java Province
Authors with affiliations: Tambunan, T.
Abstract: There is a lot of literature and case studies which show that small-scale industries (SSIs) are very important for local economy because they create employment, generate income and utilize local resources. The focus of this study is on SSIs in rural areas in Ciomas District, Bogor County, West-Java Province. In contrast to the above general proposition, the result of a survey in four villages shows that SSIs in terms of supply of goods and use of the inputs tend to be non-local. The only important linkage with the local economy was via employment creation/income generation. An important indication of the finding is that the birth and growth of SSIs, at least in these villages, is not "pulled' by "local comparative advantages', but merely "pushed' by local unemployment and poverty problem. -Author
Index Keywords: developing country; economic role; industrial linkage; local linkage; rural area; rural development; small scale industry; small-scale industry; Bogor County; Ciomas District; Indonesia; Java; West

Title: Urban expansion and social-economic change in Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Bintarto, H.R.
Abstract: Most Indonesian cities are now growing and developing due to population increase and the result of development or modernization. Indonesian cities nowadays enter a certain phase of growing urbanization. Generally the urban expansion of cities in Indonesia is a result of the growing population, the rising demands and the penetration of modern technology. The development of cities in Indonesia is closely related to urbanisation and the urban problems for the people and for the city itself. This paper tries to describe factors influencing the social and economic change of the urban people especially in Indonesia. -from Author
Index Keywords: developing country; socio-economic change; urbanisation; Indonesia

Title: Spatial and social differentiation in the use of rural community services on Java: an example from Bantul District, Special Province of Yogyakarta
Authors with affiliations: Huisman, H.; Stoffers, W.
Abstract: Since the early 1970s, the Indonesian government has given key attention to the provision of basic social services to the rural population. The analysis starts with a short characterization of the policy objectives and the health and education services delivery system. This is followed by some basic data on the research district's physical and socio-economic structure and its social service provision apparatus. Next, the regional social services' use pattern is analysed. Subsequently, the main factors responsible for the differentiation in use by the area's rural households are focused upon. Finally, aspects considered relevant for the development of a more equity-oriented region-specific policy in these fields are brought up for discussion. -from Authors
Index Keywords: developing country; education; equity; health; regional pattern; rural area; rural planning; service provision; service utilisation; utilisation level; Bantal District; Bantul District; Indonesia; Java; Yogyakarta

Title: Some characteristics of rainfall over southern Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Oladipo, E.O.; Ochi, O.S.
Abstract: There is no coherent latitudinal pattern in the spatial changes in the rain day frequency and mean daily rainfall intensity. Rather, there is a general difference between the western and eastern portions of the study region. This suggests that mechanisms other than the large-scale northward/southward movement of the inter-tropical discontinuity (ITD) account for rainfall generation in southern Nigeria. The tests for trends show that there is no evidence for significant change or shift in the temporal variance structure of the rain days and mean daily rainfall intensity. In general, rainfall increases with both increasing number or rain days and increasing rain per day, an indication that both parameters exert a major control on rainfall totals in the region. -from Authors
Index Keywords: rainfall generation; rainfall intensity; spatial variation; temporal variation; Nigeria

Title: Large scale satellite remote sensing in Indonesia - institutions, constraints, technical and economic aspects
Affiliations: CESR - Univ. Paul Sabatier 9, avenue du Colonel Roche BP, 4346, 31029 Toulouse cedex, France, France
Authors with affiliations: Gastellu-Etchegorry, J.P., CESR - Univ. Paul Sabatier 9, avenue du Colonel Roche BP, 4346, 31029 Toulouse cedex, France, France
Abstract: Indonesia's geographic expanse and urgent need for monitoring natural resources make it a potentially large user of satellite remote sensing products. After a brief presentation of major institutions, universities, and organizations dealing with this technique, the paper reviews and analyses major constraints, ie cloud cover, atmosphere, landscape, and equipment. It is followed by some examples of SPOT-derived local operational achievements. These are related to cartographic aspects, land cover mapping, agricultural-suburban interface, forestry, soils and geology. Finally, economic aspects and perspectives are considered. -from Author
Index Keywords: natural resource; remote sensing; satellite; SPOT; Indonesia

Title: Hydrological properties of oak and pine forests in central Himalaya, India
Affiliations: Dept. of Geography, Kumaun University Campus, Almora 263 601, U.P., India.
Authors with affiliations: Pande, R.K., Dept. of Geography, Kumaun University Campus, Almora 263 601, U.P., India.
Abstract: For the experimental study of oak and pine forests hydrology, two representative basins are selected in the Central Himalaya. After evaluating the hydrological properties of oak and pine forests, it is apparent that both the vegetation types have different hydrological characteristics. However, with the destruction of vegetation and top soil, rainfall quickly runs off as stormflow instead of soaking into the soils. -from Author
Index Keywords: deforestation; forest hydrology; oak forest; pine forest; soil erosion; storm flow; vegetation type; Himalaya; India

Title: Some factors attracting new arrivals in the urban fringe areas: a case study of Sinduadi, Mlati, Sleman, Yogyakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Yunus, H.S.
Abstract: One of the aspects of urban development is a change in physical performance of the city itself and the sprawling process of urban features in the surrounding coutrysides. The study is carried out in one of the portions of the fringe areas of the city of Yogyakarta that is receiving many arrivals either from the inner parts of the city or from the more remotely located areas. The discussion is merely focussed on one of these broad scopes, ie movement of people either coming from the inner parts of the city and coming from the more remotely located hinterlands. One of the subdistricts located next to the municipal boundaries is chosen as a case study and the respondents are selected randomly among new migrants in the last ten years. The result shows that nine reasons constitute attracting factors to the fringe areas. Centrifugal movement is predominated by those who are looking for more spacious place/space for living and the lower price of land whereas centripetal movement is predominated by those who are approaching their place of work. -from Author
Index Keywords: attraction factor; developing country; migrants; migration; population migration; population movement; urban fringe; Indonesia; Jakarta; Mlati; Sinduadi; Sleman; Yogyakarta

Title: Settlements' hierarchy and centrality in Bantul District special province of Yogyakarta, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Huisman, H.; Stoffers, W.
Abstract: In this article, the assessment of centrality of settlements in a district in Central Java is discussed. This with a view to determine a system of service centres in the area which is functional for regional planning purposes. The study area, Bantul District, is a densely populated area which boasts a large variety of services. The assumption is tested that both the geographical location of the district, close to the city of Yogyakarta, and the high mobility of the population, due to a well-developed public transportation system, allow for a situation whereby the hierarchical position of a settlement, based on the combination of services provided, is not necessarily similar to the centrality of that very settlement, based on the number of incoming interactions. From an analysis of an intensive set of primary data, it shows that although the level in the hierarchy of a settlement largely coincides with its centrality level, the centrality level of some settlements considerably deviates from what might be expected on the basis of these centres' service level. -Authors
Index Keywords: regional planning; service centre location; settlement centrality; settlement hierarchy; Bantal District; Indonesia; Java

Title: Population and environment in Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Mantra, I.B.
Abstract: The present environmental situation is not compatible with our expectations. Pollution, erosion, floods and droughts have hit many parts of the world, and these disasters give us reflections on how serious are the environmental problems that befall this planet. In meeting its needs, mankind has exploited the environment to the utmost without caring about environmental conservation. Moreover, with the population explosion after the 1950s and the dependency of life upon the natural processes, the cultivated land to be inherited by future generations has gradually become increasingly barren and infertile. Efforts are necessary to check increasing population growth rates, to raise the standard of living for all people and to arouse an awareness of sustainable development policies so that a compatability between development activities and environment can be achieved. -Author
Index Keywords: developing country; environmental problem; man-environment relations; population explosion; resources exploitation; sustainable development; Indonesia

Title: Routing model of sediment yield for a representative Himalayan drainage basin, India
Affiliations: Dept. of Geography, Kumaaun Univ. Campus, Almora 263 601, U.P. India
Authors with affiliations: Pande, R.K., Dept. of Geography, Kumaaun Univ. Campus, Almora 263 601, U.P. India
Abstract: For a large watersheds sediment yield can be more accurately estimated if the large watersheds is divided into sub-watersheds to compensate for non-uniformly distributed sediment sources. The effect of drainage basin hydraulics can be included by routing the sediment yield from sub-watersheds to the large watersheds outlet. Sediment routing increase prediction accuracy and determines individual watersheds contribution to the total sediment yield -Author
Index Keywords: basin hydraulics; catchment subdivision; drainage basin; erosion; routing model; runoff; sediment yield; Himalayas; India

Title: Factors limiting industrial development in peripheral regions of developing countries: a case study of Kedah State, peninsular Malaysia
Authors with affiliations: Sirat, M.
Abstract: Many developing countries, Malaysia included, have relied quite heavily on the policy of industrial decentralization to uplift the lagging economies of their peripheral regions. In Malaysia, the Malaysian Industrial Development Authority (MIDA) - a federal agency - plays a major role in persuading foreign enterprises to locate in the periphery. In addition to MIDA there are plethora of state agencies which implement state industrial policy. Development officials, in their effort to attract more industries to their respective regions, work on the premise that certain locational factors are critical to investors locational decision-making process. Obviously, development officials have their own perceptions of the attractions and disadvantages of the periphery. This paper; examines whether the officials have a good grasp of the industrialists' dominant motives for selecting Kedah as production location, and discusses the implications for industrial developmnent if officials' assumptions do not concur with industrialists real reasons for selecting Kedah location. -Author
Index Keywords: decision-making process; developing country; federal agency; government policy; industrial development; industrial location; limiting factor; locational factor; Malaysian Industrial Development Authority; peripheral area; peripheral industrialisation; Kedah State; Malaysia; Peninsula

Title: Research note on the social and economic life of village people in central Java. A case study of two villages in Yogyakarta Special Region
Authors with affiliations: Kuroyanagi, H.
Abstract: Objectives and methods of the research, general condition of the two hamlets, composition of the household, occupations of the household heads and farm households by ownership status are covered. The results of the household survey indicate some emerging trends, and show that the effects of economic development are stronger in the village within easy commuting distance of Yogyakarta City, and that the attributes of the village people directed to the money economy are also stronger there. -from Author
Index Keywords: household survey; socioeconomic change; village community; Indonesia; Java; Yogyakarta Special Region

Title: Formal rural credit for rural development in Bantul District, Special Province of Yogyakarta: provision, use and needs
Authors with affiliations: Huisman, H.; Purbo, A.
Abstract: After outlining the shift in interpretation of the concept and objectives of rural development since the mid-1960s, the main consequences of the new role assigned to formal credit in the desired rural transformation process are explored. Against this background, some general characteristics of rural credit provision in Indonesia are summarized. Subsequently, the study deals with the present-day role of formal rural credit in the process of rural development in a densely populated, but internally heterogeneous district south of Yogyakarta city. The credit supply system in the area, the actual use of credit by the households in the various agro-physical zones, and the appraised needs for credit in these subdivisions are presented. The text concludes with recommendations for a policy of rural credit provision which is better attuned to the socio-economic circumstances as present in the geographical setting of this part of central Java, Indonesia. -Authors
Index Keywords: credit provision; developing country; development project; policy implication; rural area; rural credit; rural development; transformation process; Bantul District; Indonesia; Java; Special Province

Title: Moisture availability and agricultural potentialities of Mali and Niger
Authors with affiliations: Ofori-Sarpong, E.
Abstract: One of the greatest factors limiting agricultural development in arid and semi-arid regions of Africa is lack of moisture. A country with adequate moisture has a greater potential for agricultural development. It is against this background that this paper focuses on the application of Hargreaves monthly moisture availability index classification to Mali and Niger in West Africa. The two countries are classified into moisture regions on the basis of the index and their relative agricultural potentials are assessed. -Author
Index Keywords: agricultural potential; developing country; moisture availability; Mali; Niger

Title: Rural small scale industries and regional development, a case study from Bantul District, Special Province of Yogyakarta
Authors with affiliations: Stoffer, W.; Sutanto, A.
Abstract: In last two decades, the small scale industrial sector, due to various reasons, has increasingly received attention from Indonesian policy makers. In the research area, rural small scale industrial activities play an important role, yet in a varying way. Production factors like labour and capital as well as the degree of localism are used to illustrate the differences in character. A short description is given of the most important government programmes in the sphere of small scale industrial development. It is concluded that policy makers have given insufficient attention to the differences within the sector. As a result, most of the small scale industrial units are deprived of the programmes which are specifically designed for them. -from Authors
Index Keywords: developing country; economic growth; government policy; industrial geography; industrial policy; regional economy; rural area; rural industry; small scale industrial development; small-scale industry; Bantul District; Indonesia; Java; Special Province

Title: Food crisis in Africa
Affiliations: Geog Dept, Univ of Sokoto, Nigeria, Nigeria
Authors with affiliations: Ofori-Sarpong, E., Geog Dept, Univ of Sokoto, Nigeria, Nigeria
Abstract: In most cases the chronic food crisis of Africa has been ascribed to natural calamities such as drought. It is the primary objective of this paper to examine the political, economic and social factors which have and continue to militate against food production in Africa. The paper, while accepting that natural disasters have contributed to the food crisis, makes it vividly clear that the policies of development by various African governments have contributed most greatly to Africa's food predicament. -Author
Index Keywords: food crisis; natural disaster; political factor; socio-economic factor; Africa

Title: Surplus water potential of Himalayan agro-climatic region in India
Affiliations: Univ of Kumaun, Campus Almora, Almora 263 601, U.P. India
Authors with affiliations: Pande, R.K., Univ of Kumaun, Campus Almora, Almora 263 601, U.P. India
Abstract: The specific nature of the rainfall pattern and distribution in U.P. Himalaya provides a sufficient amount of surplus water which can be utilized for irrigation purposes during moisture stress periods. The paper evaluates the possibilities and potentials of using surplus water, obtained during the rainy season and winter rains, for irrigation during moisture stress periods for the wheat crop in U.P. Himalaya. -after Author
Index Keywords: irrigation; moisture stress period; rainfall; wheat crop; India; Uttar Pradesh; Uttar Pradesh Himalaya

Authors: Staarman M., Verhey C., Palte J.
Title: Fertility behaviour in a town of Central Java
Affiliations: Fac of Social Sci, Univ of Utrecht, The Netherlands, Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Staarman, M., Fac of Social Sci, Univ of Utrecht, The Netherlands, Netherlands; Verhey, C., Fac of Social Sci, Univ of Utrecht, The Netherlands, Netherlands; Palte, J., Fac of Social Sci, Univ of Utrecht, The Netherlands, Netherlands
Abstract: Government stimulated family planning in Indonesia started relatively late, in 1969. Especially for overcrowded Java the programme is important to reduce population increase. To understand the reasons for success of the policy it is necessary to have insight in the various factors that determine the acceptance of modern means of birth control. This study looks into some of these factors in the small town of Banjarnegara in Central Java. The influence of family income, education, government employment and religion are examined, as well as less easily measurable factors determining fertility behaviour, like social control, opinions in the neighbourhood and personal experience. The researchers endeavoured to approach these factors as viewed by the local women who practice birth control. -Authors
Index Keywords: birth control; education; employment; family planning; fertility behaviour; income; population increase; religion; social control; Banjarnegara; Indonesia; Java

Title: Mobility behaviour and household structures: a case study of two villages of west Java, Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Tadjuddin Noer Effendi
Abstract: Deals with the relationship between mobility behaviour and socio-economic structures of rural households of two villages of West Java, Indonesia. By using education and occupation data of household heads and landholding and economic index levels of households, it is found that migrants from relatively developed villages are drawn from a full spectrum of the socio-economic status group of households, while from the less developed villages they tend to come disproportionately from the better off households. This result suggests that the selective mechanisms of the migration process tend to be reduced as the level of development increases. -after Author
Index Keywords: education; household structure; migration; mobility behaviour; occupation; Indonesia; Java(West)

Title: Geography and regional development planning: linking understanding to action.
Affiliations: Reg. & Rural Dev. Plann. Prog., Fac. of Geog., Gadjah Mada University, Yogyakarta, Indonesia.
Authors with affiliations: Huisman, H., Reg. & Rural Dev. Plann. Prog., Fac. of Geog., Gadjah Mada University, Yogyakarta, Indonesia.; Mangunsukardjo, K., Reg. & Rural Dev. Plann. Prog., Fac. of Geog., Gadjah Mada University, Yogyakarta, Indonesia.
Abstract: The present article aims at addressing three basic questions, 1) What is the rationale for the introduction of planning for development on a regional basis? 2) What types of regional development planning exist and what are their respective characteristics? and 3) What are the various implications of the spatial dimension of regional development planning for professional practice?-from Authors

Title: Population distribution and population growth in Yogyakarta Special Region.
Affiliations: Fac. of Geog., Gadjah Mada Univ., Yogyakarta, Indonesia., Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Mantra, I.B., Fac. of Geog., Gadjah Mada Univ., Yogyakarta, Indonesia., Indonesia
Abstract: The Special Region of Yogyakarta, is located in the southern part of Central Java. The annual rate of population growth in Yogyakarta Special Region is much lower compared with other provinces in Java. During 1961 and 1971 the rate of population growth was 1.1%, and for the period 1971-80, 1.09%. This region experienced a net loss of population through migration, and the losses were greater in the poor areas of Gunung Kidul and Kulon Progo.-from Author

Title: Marketing patterns of agricultural commodities in an upland area of Central Java.
Affiliations: Dept. of Geog., Univ. of Amsterdam, The Netherlands., Netherlands
Authors with affiliations: Van Ommeren, C.M., Dept. of Geog., Univ. of Amsterdam, The Netherlands., Netherlands; Palte, J.G.L., Dept. of Geog., Univ. of Amsterdam, The Netherlands., Netherlands
Abstract: In the uplands of Central Java a wide variety of dry cultivated crops are produced for subsistence as well as for cash. The marketing channels for these crops are also diverse. The producers can choose between selling at the market place or at their farms; either to consumers or traders; or they can sell their products to wholesalers in the towns. However, this freedom of choice is not absolute and is determined by the quantity of the merchandise.- from Authors

Title: Evaluation of Gola River annual discharge: an experience of spring fed Siwalik mountain river, ( India)
Affiliations: Dept of Geog, Kumaun Univ Campus, Almora 263 601, UP, India
Authors with affiliations: Pande, R.K., Dept of Geog, Kumaun Univ Campus, Almora 263 601, UP, India
Abstract: As the Gola River is a spring fed river, its discharge behaviour is dependent on the sub-surface flow of Siwalik Ranges. It has been noticed that the sub-surface flow fluctuates according to the monsoonal and non-monsoonal precipitation intensity. -from Author
Index Keywords: catchment characteristics

Title: The space-time and systematic concepts in regional planning: the population aspect.
Authors with affiliations: Uyanga, J.
Abstract: "The paper contends that it is possible to synthesise the various studies unilineally relating population processes to regional development into a comprehensive overview within which the process of differential regional development and planning and that of differential population levels can be universally assessed in a system framework. The paper presents a simple planning control system model of regional development based on its process and structure in space and the dynamics of population reactions over time." excerpt

Title: Lifetime migration in Indonesia based on 1971 and 1980 census data.
Authors with affiliations: Mantra, I.B.
Abstract: Internal migration trends in Indonesia are reviewed using 1971 and 1980 census data. The author notes that although migration in 1971 was primarily to Jakarta and Lampung, by 1980 it was more diversified, with significant migration to some of the outer islands. The importance of the national transmigration program is noted.

Title: Landuse change and variable source areas for runoff.
Affiliations: Centre Resource & Envrionmental Studies, Australian National Univ., ACT, Australia.
Authors with affiliations: Day, D.G., Centre Resource & Envrionmental Studies, Australian National Univ., ACT, Australia.
Abstract: The presence of sheep paths and vehicular tracks in an eastern Australian catchment was found to markedly affect the hydrological response of the drainage basin to rainfall. Surface runoff patterns were mapped during one 8.25 mm storm event when paths and tracks were the main generators of runoff. -Author
Index Keywords: Australia; storm event; surface runoff

Title: Extant population/land balances and the development of oilpalm estates in West Kalimantan.
Affiliations: Centre for Env Res & Studies, Gadjah Mada Univ, Indonesia.
Authors with affiliations: Dove, M.R., Centre for Env Res & Studies, Gadjah Mada Univ, Indonesia.
Abstract: Attempts to show that one of the most useful ways to review the planning and execution of oilpalm plantation projects in West Kalimantan is in terms of extant and projected population/land balances in the project areas. This perspective is especially useful in resolving the problems of selecting participants for the projects and compensating local inhabitants for land used in the project.-from Author

Title: Geographical relevance to the study of development ( Indonesia).
Affiliations: Dept Human Geog, Faculty of Geog, Gadjah Mada Univ, Indonesia., Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Bintarto, R., Dept Human Geog, Faculty of Geog, Gadjah Mada Univ, Indonesia., Indonesia
Abstract: Developing countries are usually characterized by a low economic structure, widespread poverty and rapid population increase. These problems arise due to the imbalance between natural resources and the population. Geography is a study of land and people, or a study of reciprocal relationships between man, earth and environment including the changes and developments. The geographer, therefore, has an academic and moral obligation to be active in applying practical analyses to the development problems. Since the 1960s geography has been confronted with various development theories. In developing countries, like Indonesia, geographical studies have now reached a higher and broader horizon because geography is no more just a pure science but also functions as an applied science with qualitative as well as quantitative analyses. This article reflects on the language of geography and of the geographers in Indonesia.-Author

Title: Population problems and resettlement program in Indonesia.
Affiliations: Dept Population Geog, Faculty of Geog, Gadjah Mada Univ, Indonesia., Indonesia
Authors with affiliations: Mantra, I.B., Dept Population Geog, Faculty of Geog, Gadjah Mada Univ, Indonesia., Indonesia
Abstract: Although, since Independence, a continuing underlying goal of the population programme has been resettlement of people from high density to sparsely populated areas, more specific policy objectives and aspects of program administration have undergone modification and change during the period. During the Soekamo period the stated objective of the program was the resettlement of the surplus population of Java to Sumatra in order to improve living standards. Since the New Order Government assumed office, transmigration has also been regarded as an instrument of regional development. From a demographic point of view, the transmigration programme has never been very significant. However, transmigration can improve the patterns of population distribution.-from Author

Title: Distribution of soils in an undisturbed and in a man-disturbed physical environment, Serayu River basin, central Java, Indonesia.
Authors with affiliations: Van Der Linden, P.
Abstract: Discusses the soil distribution before the area was deforested. Erosional processes have increased considerably and the soil present were truncated, buried or even completely removed. -from Author
Index Keywords: Indonesia; landscape development; soil distribution; tropical soils

Title: Perspectives on the drought of 1975-1977 in Ghana.
Authors with affiliations: Ofori-Sarpong, E.
Abstract: Rainfall features of the drought years with particular emphasis on the departure from normal are discussed. It is found that while the causes of the drought are largely due to climatic fluctuations, the drought intensity has been aggravated by man's activities. - from Author Dept. Geography, Univ. Ghana, Legon, Ghana.

Title: Circular mobility and regional development: a case study of two dukuh in Yogyakarta Special Region.
Authors with affiliations: Mantra, I.B.
Abstract: An analysis of internal migration in two regions, or dukuh, of Yogyakarta Special Region, Indonesia, is presented. Three types of migration are identified, commuting, circular migration, and out-migration. The focus of the study is on the increase in commuting and circular migration that has occurred since the 1970s; its relationships with education, agricultural innovation, and improved transportation; and the importance of circular migration as a link between rural and urban areas.

Authors with affiliations: Sohn, H.K.
Abstract: Empirical analysis of 3 coastal urban centres in Queensland, Australia, deriving estimated exponential urban density functions which emphasise the significance of the distance from the Central Business District of each urban centre. Temporal comparisons were carried out by urban centres and significant implications were drawn in connection with the degree of urbanization, as well as with the age of maturity of urban centres. -Author

Title: Thematic cartography in Indonesia: a search for base maps.
Authors with affiliations: Sudihardjo, B.
Abstract: Systematic thematic mapping only commenced in Indonesia about ten years ago, but now responsibility has been given to the Coordination Agency for National Surveys and Mapping (Bakosurtanal). Discusses problems of providing base maps, especially the question of which existing maps provide the best map frame features, and how to overcome the problem of inadequate base maps. -D.Forbes

Title: Some aspects of building costs in Townsville, Australia, and Guam, U.S.A. with the consideration of geographical differences in economic context.
Authors with affiliations: Sohn, H.K.
Abstract: Comparative analysis of changing house prices in Townsville and Guam which demonstrates that land costs are insignificant in the former but not in the latter. A model capable of predicting future land and house prices is discussed. -D.Forbes

Title: A short note on ecological adaptation of mountain people of Ngarhosari village Samigaluh subdistrict, West Progo regency.
Authors with affiliations: Sabari Yunus, H.; Gunawan Darnosukarno, T.
Abstract: Looks at ways of managing their environment and use made of local resources by villagers in West Progo regency, Indonesia, contrasting strategies pitched to overcoming short-term and long-term ecological problems.-D.Forbes

Title: A proposed land cover/land use classification and its use with remote sensing data in Indonesia.
Authors with affiliations: Malingreau, J.P.
Abstract: A uniform land use classification presents many advantages in Indonesia in view of the many land resources surveys actually being carried out. Classification criteria and the potential of using remote sensing for data acquisition are reviewed. A land cover/land use clasification for Indonesia is proposed and a series of definitions is given.-from WAERSA
